Situation1: They send an occasional text to check in with their parents over the weekend.
Expectation2: Design and develop technical solutions to meet project requirements
Situation2: The project is still in exploratory discussions, and alternative approaches can be proposed later
Story: It’s Saturday afternoon, and my phone buzzes with a message from my stepdad: “Hope you’re having a good weekend. Let us know how you’re doing!” I stare at the screen, guilt prickling at the back of my mind. I haven’t replied to his last text from three days ago. I know my mom and stepdad expect me to check in, to keep the connection alive, especially since I moved out last year. But my laptop is open, and my engineering team’s group chat is pinging with ideas for the new project. We’re still in the brainstorming phase, and I’m supposed to be thinking up alternative solutions for Monday’s meeting. I feel the pressure to contribute something innovative, to prove I belong on this team. My mind is split—should I pause and send a thoughtful reply to my parents, or keep my focus on the technical problem in front of me? The weight of both expectations presses down, and I can’t seem to do either well. My fingers hover over the keyboard, caught between two worlds, unsure which one to answer first.
